ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with chronic sinusitis, bronchitis, and rhinitis due to impaired mucociliary clearance. Nasal polyps are common in PCD patients.
CF commonly presents with chronic sinusitis, nasal polyps, and chronic bronchitis due to thick mucus secretions, though typically has additional GI symptoms.
Characterized by chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and rhinitis. Often associated with nasal polyps and abnormal mucus consistency.
Classic triad includes nasal polyps, chronic rhinosinusitis, and asthma/bronchitis, though aspirin sensitivity is a key feature not mentioned.
Can present with recurrent sinusitis and bronchitis, though typically includes skin manifestations and elevated IgE levels.
Presents with recurrent sinopulmonary infections including chronic sinusitis and bronchitis, though usually has broader immune dysfunction.
